newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croat-Serb customs to open in Serb enclave.
newsitem.headline: Croat-Serb customs to open in Serb enclave.

text.p: Croatian and Serb customs officers have agreed to open a joint customs service at six border crossings in the last Serb-held enclave in Croatia, a U.N. spokesman said on Monday.

"A transitional customs service...will establish their checkpoints at six different crossings on Tuesday," Yuri Chizik, spokesman for the U.N. Transitional Administration in Eastern Slavonia (UNTAES) told Reuters by telephone.
Five checkpoints will be at Eastern Slavonia's border with Yugoslavia and one with Hungary. Each will employ Croatian and Serb officers, working closely with UNTAES border monitors, he said.
The officials will wear neutral dark uniforms but will be applying Croatian customs regulations, Chizik said.
The deal followed a Memorandum of understanding signed by UNTAES and the Croatian government on Saturday.
UNTAES's 5,000 peacekeepers are overseeing the gradual return of fertile Eastern Slavonia to Zagreb's rule.
The region split from Croatian authority in a bloody war in 1991 when Zagreb declared independence from the former Yugoslav federation.
The issue of reintegration has been frought with lingering antagonism and suspicion between the Serbs who fear persecution under Croatian rule, and Croat's desire to reclaim lost property.
The process is to be completed next year. Croatia recaptured other Serb enclaves in military action last year.
